title: Former Man Utd star claims Ole Gunnar Solskjaer is 'not being allowed' to manage club
text:

Former Manchester United full back Paul Parker has slammed his ex-club and defended under-fire manager Ole Gunnar Solskjaer following the Red Devil's 1-0 loss to Newcastle.

Matty Longstaff's strike in the 72nd minute consigned United to their third defeat of the season and left them 12th in the league, just two points off the relegation zone.

The result has heaped further pressure on Solskjaer but Parker, who played for the club between 1991-1996, thinks the powers above the Norwegian are more to blame for United's recent rotten run of results.

Speaking to talkSPORT Parker said: “Everyone’s trying to turn around and blame Ole for it [but] you’ve got to remember that he’s trying to manage and coach a professional football club in the Premier League.

(Image: Action Images via Reuters)

“But he’s not been allowed to do that properly because people are not allowing him to go and bring in what he wants and allowing him to give it his best shot.

“This is a problem, it’s a problem for any club in any division of football but if you’re in the Premier League, at Manchester United and you’re not showing anything what people see as trying to win a football league then all of a sudden they’re going to be negative towards him and that’s what’s happening."

A clearly emotional Parker argued that United are putting profits above success on the pitch, and said that the club have lost their identitity.

(Image: Getty Images)

“You don’t have to be a rocket scientist or ex-player to know what the issue is at Manchester United and that’s why it’s called Manchester United," Parker added.

“They’re not Manchester United Football Club anymore because at this moment in time it’s ‘Manchester United [the brand] who come first’ and not ‘Manchester United, the football club, who should be coming first.'"

United will hope to rectify their poor recent form when they host bitter rivals and league leaders Liverpool after the international break on October 20.
description: United slumped to a 1-0 defeat against Newcastle to leave manager Solskjaer under pressure to keep his job
